WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN HOUSEWIVES EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Mrs. Martha Flint
Address Smithers B.C.
Birthplace Leicestershire England

1. INTERESTING JOURNEYS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? Near Pavan, Sask.
Where did you set up housekeeping? In the year 1906.
Where had you been living before that? In Yorkshire, England.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3.
How far was it to your nearest store? 2.5 miles after 1906.
How often could a visit be made to the store? When necessary.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? mainly necessities only.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ...........................................
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. bags.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50.
How much did you use graham flour? $2.50 for 50 lbs.
Whole wheat flour? ...........................................
Was flour milled locally? No, far away? What year? .....
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $2.50.
What other grain products did you use? ...........................................
Cornmeal? Whole wheat? Farina? ...........................................
Other? Wheat at 1.2 cents for 5 lbs.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ...........................................
How did you grind it? ...........................................

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

In the pioneer days food was sold in boxes of wood or in paper bags; wrapping paper was not used extensively.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - oatmeal cereal tea bread butter syrup
Dinner - potatoes, vegetables, meat, bread pudding & rice, dried applesauce, or stewed fruits, tea
Supper - bread butter, cold meat if any, any sweet available, tea

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

The family grew up healthy and unimpaired by any defects. Therefore the diet although lacking in variety must have been ample at all times.
